conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the width of the portion of the base through which light passes after passing through the semicircular glass brick using the properties of refraction and total internal reflection.
The angle of incidence on the flat base is \(\pi - \gamma\), and the critical angle for total internal reflection is \(\gamma\).
Using Snell's law at the flat base, \(n \sin(\pi - \gamma) = n \sin(\theta_1)\), and since \(\sin(\pi - \gamma) = \sin(\gamma)\), we find \(\sin(\theta_1) = \sin(\gamma)\).
The light ray will continue to travel in the glass until it reaches the curved surface, where the angle of incidence is \(\theta_1 = \gamma\).
Since the angle of incidence on the curved surface is exactly \(\gamma\), the light will not undergo total internal reflection and will be refracted.
Using Snell's law at the curved surface, \(n \sin(\gamma) = n' \sin(\theta_2)\), where \(n'\) is the refractive index of air (1), we find \(\sin(\theta_2) = n \sin(\gamma)\).

The light will pass through the base if the angle of refraction \(\theta_2\) is such that the light ray does not hit the base again. The maximum angle of refraction is when the light ray is tangent to the curved surface.
The light ray tangent to the curved surface will have an angle of incidence \(\gamma\) and will be refracted such that it just touches the base.
The distance from the point of incidence on the curved surface to the point where the light ray hits the base is the chord length of the semicircle corresponding to the angle \(\gamma\).
Using trigonometry, the horizontal distance from the point of incidence to the point where the light ray hits the base is \(OE = R \sin(\gamma)\).
The width of the portion of the base through which light passes is \(2OE = 2R \sin(\gamma)\).
